rationale: The species has been assessed as Data Deficient, due to a lack of information regarding population trends, or direct threats to this species across the species full range. There is evidence of population declines in parts of the species' range (e.g., Erhai Lake), and further research is required before the species can be correctly assessed.
habitat: <span>A freshwater species, found in rivers and lakes.
threats: Overfishing, pollution, and river modifications (e.g. dam construction) are major threats to this species.
population: There are some reports that the species' populations are declining (Yi 1973, Niu 2006), especially in Erhai Lake as a result of  the construction of a sluice, pollution and overfishing, and the species is likely to have declined through similar threats in other parts of the species range.
range: The species is known from the upper Yangtze River (Jinshajiang) and upper Mekong River (Lancangjiang) basins in Yunnan Province and the Caohai Lake (Guizhou Province) in China (Chu and Chen 1989, Chen 1998). The species previously spawned in Erhai Lake, however a sluice was constructed in 1973, which destroyed the spawning grounds.
useTrade: This was an important economic species for local people in the Erhai Lake region, but now it is now very rare.
conservationActions: Yun and Yi (2006) reported the artifical reproduction of the species. Research and conservation measures are required.

rationale: The species is currently known from the middle and upper Ma River in Viet Nam and Lao PDR. It is found under stones in fast flowing rivers. No further research has been carried out, therefore the species has not been observed again. Based on how little is known about this species, it is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Fast flowing rivers in rapids, on rocks and large stones (M. Kottelat pers. comm. 2011).
threats: No specific threat known but logging, deforestation and agriculture occurs in the area, with associated impacts on the aquatic environment expected (M. Kottelat pers. comm. 2011).
population: No information available.
range: The species is known from the middle and upper Nam Ma drainage in Viet Nam (Son La Province; Mai 1978) and Lao PDR (Kottelat 2001).<span>
useTrade: This species is utilized as part of local subsistence fisheries (M. Kottelat per. comm. 2011).
conservationActions: No conservation action in place.

rationale: Acanthopagrus palmaris is restricted to northwestern Australia where it is a popular angling species. There are bag limits and minimum landing sizes in place for Acanthopgarus species in the area. It is likely that this species shares biological traits with A. morrisoni. No major threats have been identified for this species. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Acanthpagrus palmaris occurs on coastal reefs, often entering estuaries (Allen et al. 2002). The maximum size for this species is 40 cm total length (Allen and Swainston 1988).
threats: There are no major threats known for this species; however, this species may be vulnerable to habitat degradation due to climate change and anthropogenic activities, as it inhabits shallow coastal waters and estuaries.
population: Population information is limited for A. palmaris.
range: Acanthopagrus palmaris is endemic to Australia and is known from Port Hedland, Western Australia and the Gulf of Carpentaria (Iwatsuki and Carpenter 2006, Greiner and Gregg 2010, Iwatsuki 2013).
useTrade: Acanthopagrus palmaris a popular angling species usually caught with hook and line and sometimes taken by prawn trawlers (Allen et al. 2002, Greiner and Gregg 2010).
conservationActions: For all Acanthopagrus species occurring in Western Australian waters, there is a minimum landing size of 25 cm and a bag limit of six fish (Department of Fisheries 2013). It also occurs in some marine protected areas within its range (World Database of Protected Areas, accessed 11 March 2014). There is a need for further study on the biology, population status, and harvest levels of A. palmaris.

rationale:
Global

Spondyliosoma cantharus is widespread and relatively common throughout most of its range where it inhabits continental waters at depths to 300 m, from Norway to Angola, including the Mediterranean and Black Seas. Spondyliosoma cantharus is commercially and recreational important throughout its range. Although global population decline has not been observed for this species, S. cantharus exhibits life history characteristics that make it particularly vulnerable to local over-exploitation. Spondyliosoma cantharus is a hermaphrodite that is slow growing, long-lived, and exhibits habitat specificity during the spawning season. It is targeted by fisheries when it forms aggregations around nesting areas, and although fishery regulations for this species are limited, marine protected areas offer protection throughout its range. Therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern. Continued monitoring of its population status and harvest levels is recommended.

Europe

In Europe, this species is widespread and relatively common. Although localized declines have been reported, there is no evidence that indicate major global declines. It is therefore listed as Least Concern.
habitat:
Spondyliosoma cantharus is a demersal species inhabiting the continental shelf, especially on seagrass beds and rocky or sandy bottoms to about 300 m depth, mainly between 10 m and 100 m (Pajuelo and Lorenzo 1999). Juveniles are found in shallower water, to about 50 m depth and will remain inshore until about two to three years of age (Pajuelo and Lorenzo 1999, Collin and Mallinson 2012). The maximum total length of this species is 60 cm (Fischer et al. 1987) and can live to about 15 years (Pajuelo and Lorenzo 1999). This species will form sizeable schools on occasion. Spondyliosoma cantharus is a relatively long-lived and slow-growing species feeding mainly on algae and small invertebrates (Pajuelo and Lorenzo 1999).  

Reproduction 
Spondyliosoma cantharus are protogynous hermaphrodites, and the age at sex-change is reported to occur at various stages (Pajuelo and Lorenzo 1999). Females of this species may reach sexual maturity around two years of age at a length of 17.3 cm TL, and males reach maturity at three years of age at a length of 22.7 cm TL (Perodou and Nedelec 1980, Soletchnik 1983, Balguerías 1995, Parjuelo and Lorenzo 1999). This species has also been reported to mature into males at approximately 20 cm, remaining as males until reaching 30 cm, with all individuals over 40 cm being female (Pawson 1995, Collins and Mallinson 2012). Sexual dimorphism in body color has been reported for this species during the spawning season and is probably associated with sexual competition, courtship and mating (Smale 1988). Spawning takes place from November to April, with a peak in spawning activity in January to February (Pajuelo and Lorenzo 1999). In the northern part of its range, S. cantharus move to deep waters in winter, and migrate inshore to breed off the United Kingdom from March to May. Spawning off Portugal occurs in the southwest from February to April, peaking in March (Gonçalves and Erzini 2000). These results are in a good agreement with those reported for the same species in the northwest African coasts, in the English Channel, and in the Cantabrian Sea (southern Bay of Biscay). This species lays eggs in a nest constructed by the males on exposed gravel or sand, with each nest containing several thousands eggs. Males of this species will protect the nest and its contents until the eggs are hatched (Collin and Mallinson 2012). The total potential annual fecundity varies between 31,670 and 554,070  (average = 292,870) eggs per female. The relative fecundity of this species reaches a maximum of 850 eggs per gram in the 30.5 cm to 31 cm length class (Dulcic et al. 1998).
threats: Spondyliosoma cantharus is an important commercially harvested fish, and thus faces threats from fisheries. The value of the exploitation rate >0.50 suggests that S. cantharus populations off the Canary Islands are heavily exploited. The value of the length at first capture (16.8 cm) is less than that of the length at first maturity and over 45% of the total catch is less than this length, indicating a danger of overfishing (Pajuelo and Lorenzo 1999). Spondyliosoma cantharus is particularly susceptible to overexploitation during its nesting season, when it aggregates around nesting sites and is then exploited by recreational and commercial fishers. This species is also vulnerable to habitat degradation from dredging, as this activity removes the coarse sediments that S. cantharus use for nest building. Spawned eggs can also be smothered by sediment deposited during dredging which inhibits embryonic development (Haskoning 2003, Collins and Mallinson 2012).
population:
Spondyliosoma cantharus is widespread and is reasonably common throughout most of its range. Spondyliosoma cantharus is abundant in shallow waters along the southern coast of the United Kingdom (Rogers et al. 1998), and the annual frequency of this species off Plymouth increased from 1913 to 2003 with the rising sea temperature as a result of climate change (Arkley and Caslake 2004). An increasing trend in abundance was also observed in the English Channel from 1993 to 2001 (Parker-Humphreys 2005). This species is heavily exploited in Portuguese waters, and the high exploitation rates suggest that this species may be locally over-fished (Gonçalves and Erzini 2000). However, global population decline has not been observed for this species.

FAO capture production data in 2012 were: Benin - three tonnes; Greece 105 tonnes; Morocco 1,598 tonnes; Senegal - 1,431 tonnes; Germany - two tonnes; Spain - 897 tonnes; France 2,667 tonnes; Netherlands - 69 tonnes; Portugal - 187 tonnes; United Kingdom 157 tonnes; Angola - 26 tonnes; Croatia - seven tonnes; Italy 70 tonnes; and Turkey - 49 tonnes.
range: Spondyliosoma cantharus is widely distributed in the eastern Atlantic, occurring from Scandinavia to Namibia, and around the Madeira, Azores, Cape Verde and Canary Islands. It is also common in the Mediterranean Sea and the western Black Sea (Bauchot and Hureau 1986, 1990). This species occurs from the surface to 300 m depth (Pajuelo and Lorenzo 1999).
useTrade: Spondyliosoma cantharus is an important commercial and food fish, and it is exploited in European waters by recreational and commercial fishers during its breeding season (Collin and Mallinson 2012). This species is fished throughout its range, particularly to the north of Senegal, where it is caught on line gear, with pelagic and bottom trawls, beach seines, fixed nets and traps (Cooper 2005, Collin and Mallinson 2012). Spondyliosoma cantharus is captured year round with significant seasonal differences in the landings (Pajuelo and Lorenzo 1999). Utilized fresh, frozen or dried salted, the flesh is highly esteemed; also reduced to fishmeal and oil (Carpenter in press). This species is regularly present in the markets of Tunisia, Morocco, Italy, Cyprus, Greece, Turkey and Sicily, and is occasionally sold elsewhere. In Portugal, this species is commercially important in inshore waters with current annual landings of c. 3,200 tonnes per year (Gonçlaves 1999, DGPA 2008).
conservationActions: In the Canary Islands, there is a minimum size limit has been implemented for Spondyliosoma cantharus. In the case of the this species, the minimum size regulation is of limited benefit because the minimum length which may be legally kept is smaller than the length at first maturity (Pajuelo and Lorenzo 1999). In European waters, there is no minimum landing size, total allowable catch and it is not subject to ICES stock assessment; however, the European Union places restrictions on any towed gears used for sea breams of a mesh size of > 80 mm, and that the bream must comprise at least 70% of the catch (EU 1998, Collin and Mallinson 2012). It is recommended that measures be taken to protect nesting areas during the spawning season (Collin and Mallinson 2012). This species occurs in some marine protected areas within its range (World Database on Protected Areas, accessed 11 March 2014).

rationale: The species is restricted to few islands in the Canaries and the Madeira islands (and possibly the Azores). The population numbers < 1,000 individuals and it is suspected to be declining as a result of habitat loss, use of agricultural pesticides, and disturbance to roosts. This species is also severely fragmented. It is assessed as Vulnerable (VU C2a(i)) but may be approaching the Endangered category.
habitat: The Murciélago de Madeira (Pipistrellus maderensis) forages over a wide range of habitats, including aquatic habitats, woodland and farmland (Trujillo 2002). It feeds on flying insects, including small moths and Diptera. Breeding colonies have been found in crevices in sea-cliffs and underneath the roofs of houses, as well as in bird boxes (Trujillo 2002). Roost sites include rock crevices, bird boxes, and crevices in (often disused) buildings. It is often associated with human settlements, although in contrast with P. pipistrellus in mainland Spain it tends not to be found in parks, gardens, and tree-lined avenues in urban areas in the Canary islands (Trujillo 2002).
threats: Restoration of buildings, covering cracks where it roosts, is a threat to the species. Rain-gauges attract dozens of bats which are trapped there and die (Trujillo 2007). Loss of natural habitat may be a threat, although the species is apparently adapted to man-made habitats. The use of agricultural pesticides may be a problem, and disturbance to roosts in buildings may also be of concern.
population: On Madeira and associated islands, it is abundant but very rare on Porto Santo. The total population is estimated to be less than 1,000 individuals, and trends are unknown (Rainho et al. 2002). On the Canary Islands it is relatively common and is the most frequently reported bat on all islands of occurrence, although no bat is abundant on the islands. Population size and trend have not been quantified (Trujillo 2002), although declines are suspected as a result of threats including loss and degradation of habitats, pesticide use, and disturbance and destruction of roosts. On the Azores, Pipistrellus bats are rare or very rare on all islands of occurrence, and the total number of individuals is probably less than 300 (Rainho et al. 2002).
range: This species is restricted to Madeira (Madeira, Porto Santo), and the western Canary Islands (La Palma, La Gomera, El Hierro, Tenerife). Pipistrelles found in the Azores (Santa Maria, Flores, Corvo, Graciosa, San Jorge) probably belong to this species. It is found from sea level to 2,150 m in the Canary Islands, although it prefers lowlands on Madeira (Fajardo and Benzal 1999).
conservationActions: The species is protected through Bern Convention, and included in Annex IV of EU Habitats & Species Directive. Rainho and Palmeirim (2002) proposed the following actions: identification, protection and monitoring of roosts; preservation and restoration of natural habitats, reduction of pesticide use; and, study of the species' biology, ecology, genetics, and systematics. Trujillo (2002) additionally recommend a public awareness campaign aimed at reducing disturbance of breeding colonies in private houses.

rationale: Tropiocolotes tripolitanus is listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, and because it is unlikely to be undergoing significant population declines that would qualify it for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This species is found in crevices and fissures in rocky plateaus and gravel desert. It prefers stony areas with fairly sparse shrub or herb cover (Trape et al. 2012). It also occurs in sandy semi-desert areas and dunes with sparse grass cover. Animals are found under stones and rocks. It has been recorded from millet fields in Niger. Animals are nocturnal and feeds on small insects, principally ants, termites and small moths (Trape et al. 2012). The female lays up to six clutches of a single egg each year.
threats: It is unlikely that any major threats affect this widespread species. It is locally threatened through the impacts of overgrazing, quarrying and off-road vehicle use causing habitat degradation. It is subject to some collection for the international pet trade but this is not a significant threat.
population: This species can occur in dense populations in suitable habitat and can be locally somewhat abundant (Trape et al. 2012), although the species is often uncommon (for instance, in Egypt).
range: This North African species is distributed across much of the Sahel and Sahara from southeastern Western Sahara and Mauritania, western, central and northern Mali, northeastern Niger, southern Algeria, and central and southern Tunisia eastwards through most of Libya and northwestern Egypt (Trape et al. 2012). It is presumed to occur in northern Chad, however, it is so far known in this country only from an area bordering Lake Chad (Trape et al. 2012).
useTrade: This species is subject to some collection for the international pet trade.
conservationActions: This species is found within protected areas throughout its range. Further studies are needed into the distribution of this species in Chad, its taxonomic status and harvest levels.

rationale:
The species is threatened by habitat degradation; habitats across most of its range have been converted into intensive farmland, developed, or polluted, especially in Thailand and Lao PDR which are its centre of population. Genetic erosion is a secondary threat from escaped farmed stock of Betta splendens into wild habitats.

Its exact Extent of Occurrence and Area of Occupancy and declining rate are poorly known currently, but is locally uncommon it its suitable habitats. Further information is needed on the species distribution and threats, and the species is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species occurs in shallow marshland and floodplains, small seasonal swamp and waterbodies with dense vegetation, grasses and small waterplants.
threats: Wetland degradation from diversion, infrastructure and agriculture may threats to this species. Hybridization from release of captive-bred specimens.
population: Locally common to uncommon throughout its range. The species is now becoming scarce in many areas across its  range due to pollution and habitat degradation.
range: This species is known from the Khorat Plateau  in northeastern Thailand and lowland Lao PDR and northern Cambodia in the Mekong and basin. Its natural range stretches  southwards from the Thai/Lao PDR border through the provinces of Nong Khai,  Udon Thani, Khon Khaen, Ubon Ratchathani and others. Possibly reported from southern Viet Nam.
useTrade: Popular locally in aquarium trade and in specialist international trade. Used for fighting game fish.
conservationActions: Habitat management and awareness raising on captive releasing are recommended.

rationale: The species is presently known only from a very short stretch (c.2 km long) of a branch  of the upper Nam Phao, a tributary of the Nam Theun in the Mekong drainage in Lao PDR. It inhabits very fast water with waterfalls and large rocks and it feeds in grazing algae and invertebrates at the surface of rocks; sedimentation eliminates its source of food and habitat. It might have a greater range but the area could not yet be surveyed. The only known stretch is along a road  going to the border with Viet Nam, impacted by road maintenance and by wastes from the shops and other border businesses along the road. The other stretches of the Nam Phao are filled with sediments and have no suitable habitat. The river also receives domestic wastes from Laksao and pollution from a gold mine. Because of its very restricted EOO and AOO, and the quantity and  variety of threats this species is assessed as Critically Endangered.  Surveys are needed to confirm the species distribution, and it should be reassessed if further data show that the species has a wider distribution.
habitat: Inhabits a stretch of the stream with waterfalls and large rock bottom. Grazes algae on rocks.
threats: The species is presently known only from a very short stretch of a branch of the upper Nam Phao, about 2 km long. This stretch is along the road leading to the border, which is now crowded by shops and other businesses, and domestic waste enters into the stream. Adjacent streams could not yet be surveyed. Below this point, the stream joins with the Nam Phao which is totally filled with sediments resulting from the construction of a small hydropower reservoir. The recent maintenance of the road going to Vietnam, along the river, also resulted in huge quantities of material being pushed into the river. The river is filled with sediment almost until its confluence with the Nam Theun. In addition the lower Nam Phao receives wastes from Laksao and pollution from a gold mine on one of its tributaries. As the species grazes algae on the rocks, once the rocks are covered by sediment the food disappears.
population: No information available.
range: The species is known only from a short section (c.2 km long) of a small tributary of the upper Nam Phao, a tributary of the Nam Theun, in the Mekong drainage in Lao PDR (Bolikamsai Province), almost on the border with Viet Nam. It might be present elsewhere in adjacent streams, but survey has not yet been possible.
useTrade: Part of subsistence fisheries.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are in place. Surveys are needed to ascertain the species' exact distribution.

rationale: This species is known from river basins in Myanmar, where it is found in clear water swamps. It has been collected in relatively large numbers during surveys carried out over the past two decades, but no other information is available. Considering the little information known, this species is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species lives in clear water swamps (L. Parenti pers. comm. 2011).
threats: Threats include habitat destruction and degradation caused by urban development and agriculture.
population: It has been collected in relatively large numbers during surveys carried out over the past two decades, but no other information is available (Parenti 2008).
range: This species is known from the Ayeyarwaddy, Hlaing (Rangoon) and Sittaung basins, Myanmar (Roberts 1998, Parenti 2008).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are known.

rationale: This species is widely distributed throughout the Mekong basin in northeast Thailand, Lao PDR and Cambodia, where it lives in clear water swamps, and is found in anthropogenic habitats. Little is known about the populations of this species, although it is frequently encountered in surveys. Whilst habitat destruction and degradation caused primarily by urban development and also agriculture may impact the species, it is assessed as Least Concern at present.
habitat: This species lives in clear water swamps (Kottelat 2001). It may be associated with acidic waters (Roberts 1998). According to Rainboth  (1996) it occurs in canals, ditches and ponds, especially those in which  fine-leaved aquatic plants grow densely.
threats: Habitat destruction and degradation caused primarily by urban development and also agriculture.
population: Little is known about the populations of this species, although it is frequently encountered in surveys (Magtoon 2010).
range: This species is widely distributed throughout the lower Mekong basin in northeastern Thailand, Lao PDR and Cambodia (Kottelat 2001).
useTrade: This species infrequently occurs in the international aquarium trade and may be captive bred (L. Parenti pers. comm. 2011).
conservationActions: There are no conservation actions in place for this species. Indirect protect from local participatory wetland programme and reserve zone in some of its habitats.

rationale: This species is known from the Mekong and Chao Phraya basins in Cambodia, Lao PDR, Thailand and Viet Nam. It is a live-bearing fish which lives in shallow, slow moving streams and standing water. Habitat degradation caused by a variety of anothropogenic infrastructure activities may impact this species and it occasionally occurs in the international aquarium trade. Although little is known of the species, it has a wide distribution and is without major known threats, and is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This is a live-bearing species which lives in shallow, slow moving streams and standing water (Kottelat 2001). A small carnivorous species, found at the surface of small water bodies with vegetation.
threats: Habitat degradation caused by a variety of anthropogenic infrastructure activities (L. Parenti pers. comm. 2011).
population: There is no population information available.
range:
The species is known from the Mekong and Chao Phraya basins in Cambodia, Lao PDR (Baird 1999), Thailand and Viet Nam (Kottelat 2001). In the Mekong, the species is found as far upstream as the Mun River (Thailand) and the Champon and Banghiang tributaries in Lao PDR (Baird et al. 1999).

The species is also reported (MRC 2003) from Malaysia (Mohsin and Ambak 1983) and Indonesia (Rainboth 1996, Kottelat et al. 1993), however these records require confirmation, and perhaps refer to another Dermogenys species.
useTrade: This species occasionally occurs in the international aquarium trade (L. Parenti pers. comm. 2011), and is likely to be found in mixed fisheries.
conservationActions: There are no conservation actions known. Research is needed.

rationale: This species is widespread in the Indo-West Pacific and is common throughout its range and can be locally abundant. Its habitat (mangroves, estuaries, rivers) is highly impacted by human activities and there have been reported declines in habitat quality and losses in its range of distribution. The effects of human impacts to this species is undetermined, there is no evidence at present time indicating population declines from habitat degradation. It is therefore listed as Data Deficient. We recommend continued monitoring of this species' habitat and population status.
habitat: This species inhabits mangroves, estuaries, lower reaches of freshwater streams, and harbours with freshwater discharge. It is also found in pure fresh water, but is always within a few kilometres of the sea (Allen 1991). It occurs in brackish waters of coastal embayments and mangrove estuaries (Allen et al. 2002). Spawning may take place in both brackish and fresh waters (Allen 1991). This species feeds on zooplankton. In Tonga, during a survey of the area, only one member of this species was recorded. It was found on a fringing reef in association with high coral and low algal cover at a depth of 4.1 m. In New Caledonia, this species is common on fringing reefs, but is extremely rare on inner barrier reefs. It is associated with very low coral and very high algal cover at an average depth of 2 m (Mellin et al. 2006).
threats: This species is a minor component of the aquarium trade. It is also threatened by habitat degradation, (mangroves - Polidoro et al. 2010; freshwater - Jenkins et al. 2010).
population: This species is common throughout its range and locally abundant. This species is extremely rare in Tonga. It is relatively rare in New Caledonia (Mellin et al. 2006).
range: This species is found at the continental margin of Indian Ocean and western Pacific including East Africa from Mozambique northwards, India, Sri Lanka, countries bordering South China Sea, Indonesia, Philippines, Palau, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, New Caledonia, and northeastern Australia.  It has also been reported from Taiwan (Shen 1993).
useTrade: This species is a minor component of the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. Its distribution overlaps with some protected areas in parts of its range. More research is needed regarding population trends and life history.

rationale: This species is known from southern China, including Hainan Island, Hong Kong and Guangdong and Quang Ninh Province, Viet Nam, where it occurs in still waters in coastal brackish to freshwater habitats. It was once very abundant in its known range, but the population has been slowly decreasing over the past 20 years, especially in China. This species infrequently occurs in the international aquarium trade and may be captive bred. Habitat destruction and degradation caused primarily by urban development and also agriculture. Based on the little information currently known about this species, it is assessed as Data Deficient. More information is needed on geographic range and population as this species could become threatened.
habitat: This species occurs in still waters in coastal brackish to freshwater habitats (Uwa and Parenti 1988, Parenti 2008).
threats: Habitat destruction and degradation caused primarily by urban development and also agriculture.
population: This species was once very abundant in its known range, but the population has been slowly decreasing over the past 20 years, especially in China (L. Parenti pers. comm. 2011).
range: Distributed throughout southern China, including Hainan Island, Hong Kong and Guangdong and Quang Ninh Province, northern Viet Nam (Kottelat 2001), where it was been collected during surveys carried out at specific sites. The full extent of the geographic range of this species is not known (Parenti 2008)
useTrade: This species infrequently occurs in the international aquarium trade and may be captive bred (L. Parenti pers. comm. 2011).
conservationActions: There are no conservation actions in place for this species.

rationale: This species was described from the Mekong delta, Viet Nam, where it occurs in coastal tidal habitats, and has recently been recorded from southeastern Thailand, and presence in coastal areas of Cambodia is likely. The majority of habitat within the range of this species is likely to be impacted by anthropogenic activities, but the level of severity is unknown. Based on how little is known about this species, it is assessed as Data Deficient.
habitat: This species occurs in coastal tidal habitats (Parenti 2008); Magtoon (2011) found a specimen in brackish water in coastal mangroves.
threats: Habitat destruction and degradation caused primarily by urban development and also agriculture.
population: No information on population is available.
range: This species was thought to be restricted to the Mekong delta, southern Viet Nam (Roberts 1998, Parenti 2008). Recorded from the Dong Nai River (Freyhof et al. 2000), and there is a recent record from southeastern Thailand (Bangkaja Sub-district, Mueang, Trat Province; Magtoon 2011). The species should be looked for in Cambodia.
useTrade: No fisheries interest.
conservationActions: There are no conservation actions in place for this species.

rationale: The species is only known from Ba Bê Lake and the Nang River  drainage in northern Viet Nam (Bác Can Province; Nguyen and Ngo 2001). Whilst there are known threats to the species in the lake, management of the lake is improving, and nothing is known of population in rivers, which is impacted by sedimentation. The species is assessed as Data Deficient and further research is required to confirm the taxonomic identity of the species.
habitat: The species is known from a freshwater river and lake.
threats: Ba Bê Lake is impacted by a number of threats including illegal timber and firewood collection for domestic use; continued occupation of agricultural land within the national park; grazing of cattle within the national park; pollution of lake waters due to dynamite and poison fishing techniques; sedimentation of the lake due to agricultural practices in the catchments of the three rivers that feed it; infrastructure development and unsustainable tourism development. A road has recently been constructed around the southern shore of Ba Bê Lake, increasing disturbance and facilitating access to natural resources within the national park (Birdlife Indochina 2010). The Nang River is impacted by sedimentation.
population: There is no information available on the species population.
range: The species is presently known from Ba Bê Lake and the Nang River drainage in northern Viet Nam (Bác Can Province) only (Nguyen and Ngo 2001).  The area of the lake is between 5 and 8 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: Not known.
conservationActions: Ba Bê Lake is a national park and has also been designated a Ramsar Site.

rationale: This species occurs in the Mekong, Chao Phraya, Mae Khlong basins and in the northern Malay Peninsula. It is widely distributed and  common throughout its range, where it occurs in moving waters with gravel to stone substrate and  aquatic vegetation. Anthropogenic modification of river morphology impacts this species by reducing or interrupting fast water flow. Logging, deforestation and agriculture also occur in the area, with associated impacts on the aquatic environment expected. This species is assessed as Least Concern as it is widely distributed and seems less sensitive to minor habitat changes compared to species with similar habitat preferences.
habitat: This species occurs in moving waters with gravel to stone substrate and aquatic vegetation. This species seems less sensitive to minor habitat changes compared to species with similar habitat preferences (M. Kottelat pers. comm. 2011).
threats: Anthropogenic modification of river morphology impacts this species by reducing or interrupting water flow. Logging, deforestation and agriculture occurs in the area, with associated impacts on the aquatic environment expected (M. Kottelat per. comm. 2011).
population: This species is widely spread and common throughout its range (Kottelat 1989, M. Kottelat pers. comm. 2011).
range: This species is widely distributed in southeast Asia. It occurs in the Mekong, Chao Phraya, Mae Khlong basins and in the northern Malay Peninsula (Kottelat 1989, M. Kottelat pers comm. 2011).
useTrade: This species is utilized as part of local subsistence fisheries (M. Kottelat per. comm. 2011).
conservationActions: Parts of this species range occurs within Protected Areas.

rationale: This species is found in the Sekong drainage in Lao PDR. It is uncommon, but this is possibly because the preferred habitat (rapids and fast flowing waters in main river and larger tributaries, with stretches of river with large gravel) is not easily sampled. This species is utilized as part of local subsistence fisheries and it occasionally occurs in the aquarium fish trade. Anthropogenic modification of river morphology impacts this species by  reducing or interrupting fast water flow. Dams are constructed (on the Xe Kaman) or planned that will impact its habitat. Logging, deforestation and  agriculture occurs in the area, with associated impacts on the aquatic  environment expected. This species is assessed as Data Deficient because not enough information is known about its population trends, distribution, or the impact of threats.
habitat: Found in rapids and fast flowing waters in the mainriver and larger tributatries. Also in stretches of river with large gravel (M. Kottelat pers. comm. 2011).
threats: Anthropogenic modification of river morphology impacts this species by reducing or interrupting fast water flow. Logging, deforestation and agriculture occurs in the area, with associated impacts on the aquatic environment expected (M. Kottelat pers. comm. 2011). Dams are constructed (on the Xe Kaman) or planned that will impact its habitat by sedimentation and reduction of flow.
population: This species is uncommon, but this is possibly because the preferred habitat is not easily sampled (M. Kottelat pers. comm. 2011).
range: This species is found in the Sekong drainage in Lao PDR (Kottelat 2001, Roberts 1997).
useTrade: This species is utilized as part of local subsistence fisheries and it occasionally occurs in the aquarium fish trade (M. Kottelat pers. comm. 2011).
conservationActions: No conservation action is in place. Research is required to understand the impacts of known threats.

rationale: Chromis cinerascens is widely distributed in the Indo-West Pacific. It is common and locally abundant. Although it is commonly found in coral reef areas, it is not closely dependent on corals, and is found over a depth range that provides insulation against coral reef degradation. There are no major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Chromis cinerascens inhabits sheltered waters with periodic strong currents, often in water that is very turbid (G. Allen pers. comm. 2010). It is found on silty inshore reefs, not necessarily rich in coral, and often on coastal reefs with rocky ledges, at depths between about 3-15 m (Allen and Erdmann 2012). It feeds on zooplankton and is often found in areas dominated by soft corals, although it is not reliant on healthy coral reefs.
threats: The habitat of this species may be impacted by dynamite fishing in some areas.
population: This species is common and locally abundant.
range: Chromis cinerascens is found in the eastern Indian Ocean and western Pacific including Sri Lanka, Andaman Sea, Malaysia, Indonesia, Hong Kong, Brunei, Philippines, and northwestern Australia (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place, but there are marine protected areas throughout its range (IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2016).

rationale: Amphiprion perideraion is widely distributed in the Indo-West Pacific. It is common and locally abundant, and there are no major threats. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Amphiprion perideraion inhabits lagoons and seaward reefs (Myers 1991). It is a commensal inhabitant of sea anemones (Heteractis magnifica) on coral reefs in depths between about 3-20 m. This species is a protandrous hermaphrodite (Moyer and Nakazono 1978). In Bali, it occurs together with the closely related Indian Ocean species, A. akallopison, and even has been found sharing the same anemone (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001). One pair spawns several times per year, and annual fecundity for this species is estimated to be 2,000 to 4,000 eggs. Size at sex change is 5.4 cm TL (Allsop and West 2003).
threats: Amphiprion perideraion is collected for the aquarium trade, and may be affected by dynamite fishing in some areas. Its anemone host may be susceptible to bleaching events.
population: Amphiprion perideraion is common and locally abundant. In northern Papua New Guinea, its population has remained stable over the last 13 years (A. Jenkins pers. comm. 2010).
range: Amphiprion perideraion is located in the western Pacific in the Gulf of Thailand and Cocos-Keeling in the eastern Indian Ocean to Samoa and Tonga, north to the Ryukyu Islands, south to Australia (Western Australia and the Great Barrier Reef) and New Caledonia (Meyers 1991, Allen and Erdmann 2012).
useTrade: This species is collected for the aquarium trade.  It has been reared in captivity (Miyagawa 1989, Moe 1992, Gardner 1997).
conservationActions: This species is present in marine protected areas throughout its range.

rationale: Amphiprion percula is found in the central western Pacific. It is common and locally abundant. There are no major threats; therefore, this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Amphiprion percula inhabits lagoons and seaward reefs (Lieske and Myers 1994). Each group of fish consists of a breeding pair and up to four non-breeders. Within each group there is a size-based hierarchy: the female is largest, the male is second largest, and the non-breeders get progressively smaller as the hierarchy is descended. If the female dies, the male changes sex and becomes the breeding female, while the largest non-breeder becomes the breeding male. The maintenance of size differences may avoid conflicts, because subordinates do not become a threat to their dominants (Buston 2003). Appears to occur in shallower depths than A. ocellaris.
threats: Amphiprion percula is collected in the aquarium trade, and it occurs in areas subject to dynamite fishing. The host anemones may be vulnerable to periodic bleaching events.
population: This species is common and locally abundant. In northern Papua New Guinea, there has been a significant increase in its population over the last 13 years (A. Jenkins pers. comm. 2010).
range: Amphiprion percula is located in the western Pacific off Queensland and Melanesia, including the northern Great Barrier Reef, northern New Guinea, New Britain, Solomon Islands and Vanuatu (Allen and Erdmann 2012). Members of this species are often confused with A. ocellaris (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
useTrade: This species is collected for the aquarium trade. It has been reared in captivity (Moe 1992, Gardner 1997, Job et al. 1997).
conservationActions: This species is found in marine protected areas throughout its range. In the Australian portion of its range, the collection for the aquarium trade is strictly regulated.

rationale: Altrichthys curatus is found in a limited range in the Philippines and its area of occupancy (AOO) is approximately 1,300 km² based on its coral habitat. This species does not have a pelagic larval stage and the young are cared for by the parents. Coral reefs are in decline due to global (e.g., climate change, ocean acidification) and local (e.g., destructive fishing practices, pollution) factors.We infer its population is declining based on declines in coral cover that are common in this region. It is known from only one location, and its habitat is declining in area and quality. Therefore, this species is listed as Vulnerable under criterion B (VU B2ab(iii,v)).
habitat: Altrichthys curatus is found on sheltered coastal reefs in rich coral areas between depths of about 0.5-10 m, where zooplankton is the main source of this fish's diet. It is closely associated with branching corals, particularly Porites cylindrica and Echinopora horrida. Unlike most pomacentrids, this species lacks a pelagic larval stage and the young are cared for by the parents (Allen 1991). Parental care is associated with territoriality, therefore this species may be more susceptible to habitat loss than other pomacentrids.
threats: This species is likely to be impacted by loss of coral cover, which is common in this region. Coral reefs are in decline due to global (e.g., climate change, ocean acidification) and local (e.g., destructive fishing practices, pollution) factors (Arceo et al. 2001, Bruno and Selig 2007).
population: Currently this species is common and locally abundant (G. Allen pers. comm. 2010). It is associated with areas of live coral, and, because of continued degradation of coral reefs within its range, its population is declining.
range: Altrichthys curatus is located in the Philippines at Calamianes and Cuyo island groups (Allen 1999) and the northern tip of Palawan (G. Allen pers. comm. 2010). Based on this distribution and coral habitat (UNEP-WCMC et al. 2010), we estimate its AOO to be about 1,300 km².
useTrade: There is no use/trade information for this species.
conservationActions: This species is found in several marine protected areas (MPAs); however, the efficacy of these MPAs is uncertain.

rationale: This species is common and locally abundant. There are no major threats; therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Chromis amboinensis inhabits coral-rich areas of clear lagoon and seaward reefs at depths between 5-65 m (Allen 1991). While it is more common on steep outer reef slopes, usually below about 20 m, C. amboinensis is relatively uncommon in lagoons. This species feeds on zooplankton, and is territorial and often occurs singly, or occasionally in pairs, or in small loose groups (Allen pers. comm. 2010). The maximum recorded length for this species is 10 cm SL (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
threats: Chromis amboinensis is occasionally collected in the aquarium trade, and its habitat is subject to dynamite fishing in parts of its range.
population: Chromis amboinensis is common and locally abundant. In northern Papua New Guinea, its population has remained stable over the last 13 years (A. Jenkins pers. comm. 2010).
range: Chromis amboinensis is found from the Indo-Australian Archipelago eastward to Samoa and the Marshall Islands. It also occurs in the eastern Indian Ocean at Christmas Island, and the reefs of Australia's Northwest Shelf (Allen 1991). This species is found at depth ranging from 5 to 70 m (Myers 1991).
useTrade: Chromis amboinensis is occasionally collected in the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures for C. amboinensis; however, its range overlaps with a number of marine protected areas (IUCN and UNEP 2014).

rationale: This is common species found throughout much of its range and there are no major threats. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Chromis atripes inhabits steep outer reef slopes and deeper patch reefs at depths between about 10-35 m (Allen 1991). It is territorial and usually occurs singly or occasionally in pairs or small, loose groups near the bottom of the reef, and feeds on zooplankton (G. Allen pers. comm. 2010). The maximum recorded length for this species is 9 cm TL (Masuda et al. 1984).
threats: Chromis atripes is occasionally collected in the aquarium trade, and its habitat is subject to dynamite fishing in parts of its range.
population: This species is common and locally abundant.
range: Chromis atripes is found in the Western Pacific and eastern edge of Indian Ocean including southern Japan, Ryukyu Islands, Philippines, Indonesia, Palau, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, New Caledonia, Loyalty Islands, Kiribati, Australia, and Christmas Island (Indian Ocean) (Allen 1991). It was recently reported from Tonga (Randall et al. 2003). This species is found at depths ranging from 10 to 35 m (Allen 1991).
useTrade: It is occasionally collected in the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures for C. atripes; however, its range overlaps with a number of marine protected areas (IUCN and UNEP 2014).

rationale: Amblyglyphidodon leucogaster is widely distributed in the western Pacific Ocean. This species is common and locally abundant. Although it is subjected to dynamite blasting in some areas of its range, no population declines have been reported; therefore this species is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Amblyglyphidodon leucogaster inhabits lagoons, reef passages, and the outer reef slopes at depths of 2-45 m as solitary individuals or in small groups. It feeds on copepods, amphipods, mysids, fish eggs, crustacean larvae, and a small portion of algae. This species is adaptable to disturbed habitats (A. Jenkins pers. comm. 2010).
threats: In Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines, this species is found in areas that are subjected to dynamite blasting.
population: Amblyglyphidodon leucogaster is common and locally abundant (Allen 1991). Despite coral loss in northern Papua New Guinea, transects indicate that the population has remained stable over the last 13 years (A. Jenkins pers. comm. 2010).
range: Amblyglyphidodon leucogaster is mainly distributed around the western rim of the Pacific Ocean, including the Ryukyu Islands, China, the Philippines, East Indies, and Melanesia. It is also known from the Caroline and Marshall islands, off shore reefs of Western Australia (Scott, Seringapatam, and Ashmore reefs), Andaman Sea coast of Thailand, and northwest Sumatra (Weh Island) (Allen 1991).
useTrade: There is no use/trade information for this species.
conservationActions: This species is found in marine protected areas throughout its range.

rationale: This species is found from the Andaman and Nicobar Islands to Java, Indonesia. It is common, with are no major threats. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Amphiprion ephippium is found in silty coastal waters and protected bays where visibility is often reduced. This species is a commensal inhabitant of sea anemones (Entacmaea quadricolor and Heteractis crispa) on coral reefs in depths between about 1-15 m, and are usually found in pairs (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001).
threats: Amphiprion ephippium is collected in the aquarium trade, and occurs in areas subject to dynamite fishing. In addition, the host anemones may be vulnerable to periodic bleaching events.
population: This species is locally common.
range: Amphiprion ephippium is located off the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, west coast of Thailand, Malaysia, Sumatra, and Java (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
useTrade: This species is collected in the aquarium trade. It has been reared in captivity (Moe 1992, Gardner 1997).
conservationActions: This species occurs in marine protected areas throughout its range.

rationale: This species is common throughout its range and its population is considered stable. There are no known major threats; therefore it is listed as Least Concern. However, taxonomic uncertainty remains as to the validity of geographically separated colour morphs. If this nominal species is redefined as a more localized species, this assessment will need to be reviewed.
habitat: A non-migratory species, Acanthochromis polyacanthus inhabits inshore and offshore coral reefs at depths between 1-65 m, but usually occurs above 15 m (Lieske and Myers 1994). It is also found in harbors, lagoons and outer reef slopes. This is one of only three pomacentrid species that lacks a pelagic larval stage, and is one of the very few marine fishes where fry are guarded by the parents (Lieske and Myers 1994, Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001). This species schools as it grows, and sub-adults are usually seen in small groups. Adults form pairs and are territorial when breeding (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001), and are monogamous (Whiteman and Côté 2004).
threats: This species is potentially threatened by exploitation for the aquarium trade, but it is limited. It may also be impacted by dynamite fishing in the Philippines and Indonesia.
population: This species is common and is considered to be stable.  The taxonomic status of numerous geographic colour variants in New Guinea and Australia requires study (Allen 1991).
range: Acanthochromis polyacanthus is located in the Indo-Australian Archipelago including northern Australia, Indonesia, Philippines, Papau New Guinea, Malaysia (Sabah), Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, and New Caledonia (Allen 1991). It has also been recorded in the central Caroline Islands. Records from Mentawi Islands (off southern Sumatra) by Kunzman et al. (1999) and from the Seribu Islands (Java Sea) by Allen and Adrin (2003) need to be confirmed.
useTrade: This species occasionally enters the aquarium trade, and occurs on reefs that are often blasted during dynamite fishing in the  Philippines and Indonesia.
conservationActions: This species responds well to protection in the form of MPAs (Jenkins et al. 2004).  Recent data indicate that this trend is continuing in these studied MPAs (A. Jenkins pers. comm. 2010).

rationale: Altrichthys azurelineatus is found within a limited range in the Philippines and its area of occupancy (AOO) is approximately 1,400 km² based on its coral habitat. This species does not have a pelagic larval stage and the young are cared for by the parents. Coral reefs are in decline due to global (e.g., climate change, ocean acidification) and local (e.g., destructive fishing practices, pollution) factors. We infer its population is declining based on declines in coral cover and area that are common in this region. It is known from only one location, and its habitat is declining in area and quality. Therefore, this species is listed as Vulnerable under criterion B (VU B2ab(iii,v)).
habitat: This species is found on sheltered coastal reefs in rich coral areas between depths of about 0.5-10 m with an average depth of 3-4 m. It is closely associated with branching corals, particularly Porites cylindrica and Echinopora horrida. Zooplankton is the main source of this fish's diet. Unlike most pomacentrids, this species lacks a pelagic larval stage and the young are cared for by the parents (Allen 1991). Parental care is associated with territoriality, therefore this species may be more susceptible to habitat loss than other pomacentrids.
threats: This species is likely to be impacted by loss of coral cover, which is common in this region. Coral reefs are in decline due to global (e.g., climate change, ocean acidification) and local (e.g., destructive fishing practices, pollution) factors (Arceo et al. 2001, Bruno and Selig 2007).
population: Currently this species is common and locally abundant (G. Allen pers. comm. 2010). It is associated with areas of live coral, and, because of continued degradation of coral reefs within its range, its population is declining.
range: Altrichthys azurelineatus is only known from the Philippines in the western Central Pacific, specifically from the Calamianes Islands and northern Palawan (Allen 1991). Based on this distribution and its coral habitat (UNEP-WCMC et al. 2010), we estimate its AOO to be about 1,400 km².
useTrade: There is no use/trade information for this species.
conservationActions: This species is found in several marine protected areas (MPAs), however, the efficacy of these MPAs is uncertain.

rationale: This species is found in the Coral Triangle Region in a variety of coastal habitats, where it is common and can be locally abundant. Because of its wide range, it is assessed as Least Concern. However, this species is threatened by significant loss of its mangrove and freshwater habitat due to a range of human disturbances, although populations are reported to be increasing and recovering in parts of its range. Continued monitoring of this species' habitat and population status is recommended alongside research on the effects of habitat loss.
habitat: This species is solitary or occurs in small groups in lagoons, mangrove shores, harbours, coastal reefs and outer reef slopes, frequently among branching alcyonarians.  It is also found in mangrove creeks, sometimes in freshwater, brackish lagoons and shallow reefs exposed to freshwater runoff at depths between 0-5 m. It can be found well upstream in pure freshwater (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001).  This species feeds primarily on benthic algae and can reach a maximum size of about 9.5 cm SL (G.R. Allen pers. comm. 2019).
threats: Threats to this species include deforestation and mining. Often many hundreds of kilometres inland these practices have led to large increases in sediment loads which have smothered coral reefs and other coastal habitats in Malaysia (Gray 1997), and freshwater quality is declining due to a range of human disturbances (Jenkins et al. 2010). There have been significant mangrove area loss, with an estimated 30% reduction in mangrove area since 1980 in the Indo-Malay Philippine Archipelago (Polidoro et al. 2010).
population: This species is common in parts of its range and can be locally abundant (G.R. Allen pers. comm. 2010). The overall population trend is unknown, but it may be impacted by the threats of habitat degradation and destruction throughout its range. Populations were reported to be increasing in Santiago, Bolinao Philippines reef areas and were recovering from dynamite blasts in Jakarta Bay Indonesia (Aktani 2003) and in Oyster Reefs in Taiwan.
range: This species is found in the Coral Triangle from Sabah (Malaysia) and Kalimantan to Flores, West Papua (Indonesia), eastern Papua New Guinea, and the Solomon Islands, north to Palau, the Philippines, Taiwan and the Ryukyu Islands (Japan) (G.R. Allen pers. comm. 2019).
useTrade: There is no use or trade information available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. However, its distribution overlaps with some marine protected areas in parts of its range. Continued monitoring of this species' habitat and population status is recommended alongside research on the effects of habitat loss.

rationale: Amphiprion frenatus is relatively widespread in the western Pacific Ocean. It is common with no major threats. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Amphiprion frenatus is found in lagoon reefs and embayments. It is a commensal inhabitant of sea anemone (Entacmaea quadricolor) on coral reefs in depths between about 1-15 m. This species is monogamous and is a protandrous hermaphrodite (Whiteman and Côté 2004). It is a benthic spawner with a length at sex change of 6.6 cm TL. Amphiprion frenatus has been reared in captivity (Miyagawa 1989, Juhl 1992, Moe 1992, Gardner 1997).
threats: Amphiprion frenatus is collected in the aquarium trade, occurs in areas subject to dynamite fishing, and may be taken as by-catch in some areas. The host anemone may be vulnerable to periodic bleaching events.
population: This species is locally common.
range: Amphiprion frenatus is located in the South China Sea, Borneo, Sumatra, Philippines, Taiwan, and southern Japan (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
useTrade: This species is collected in the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: This species is present in marine protected areas throughout its range.

rationale: Amphipriprion akallopisos is widespread in the Indian Ocean. It is common in parts of its range, and can be locally abundant. It is harvested for the aquarium trade, but there is no evidence of population declines from harvesting. Its habitat is threatened by illegal fishing practices in parts of its range (specifically Indonesia); however, its distribution overlaps with a number of marine protected areas in parts of its distribution. Therefore, it is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Amphipriprion akallopisos is found in shallow inshore reef habitats, often in strong current zones (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001). Individuals of this species are protandrous hermaphrodites, and each pair is monogamous (Alsop and West 2003). This species is a commensal inhabitant of sea anemones (Heteractis magnifica and Stichodactyla mertensii) on coral reefs in depths between about 1-25 m (Allen 1991). Each anemone is home to a large female, a smaller functional male and several stunted juveniles; with the removal of the female, the male changes sex and the largest of the juveniles develops into a functional male (Allen 1986). Sex reversal is completed in less than 63 days (Sadovy and Shapiro 1987). The length of individuals at the time of a sex change is 7.2 cm TL (Allsop and West 2003). This species is a benthic spawner and may be reared in captivity (Moe 1992).
threats: This species is harvested for the aquarium trade, and host anemones are susceptible to bleaching events. Illegal fishing practices (dynamite fishing) in the Indonesian portion of its range is prevalent, contributing to its habitat degradation.
population: This species is common in parts of its range, and can be locally abundant (Allen 1991, G.R. Allen and R.F. Myers pers. comm. 2010).
range: Amphipriprion akallopisos is widespread in the Indian Ocean from East Africa to Bali (including the Comoro Islands, Madagascar, Seychelles and Sri Lanka), and north to Socotra (Zajonz et al. 2000) and the Andaman Islands. It is replaced by the similar species A. nigripes in the Maldives (G.R. Allen and R.F. Myers pers. comm. 2010).
useTrade: This species is a component of the aquarium trade.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species, however its distribution overlaps with some marine protected areas in parts of its range.

rationale: This species is fairly widespread and currently is locally abundant in parts of its range. However, it is closely associated with branching Acropora corals that have undergone significant declines in the area where this species is found. Direct observation indicates declines of up to 75% in marine protected areas over the past 13 years in northern Papua New Guinea. Where this species occurs, somewhere between 30 and 50% of Acropora species are threatened with extinction. We infer that over its range this species has declined greater than 30% due to habitat loss from Acropora degradation. Because this species is locally abundant in some parts of its range, we infer that overall losses are somewhere between 30 and 50% over three generation lengths (9-12 years, which corresponds approximately to the generation length used for Acropora). Therefore, this species is listed as Vulnerable under criterion A (VU A2bc).
habitat:
Amblyglyphidodon ternatensis is common among coral-rich areas of sheltered coastal reefs with algae and staghorn corals to about 15 m depth, but more common from 1-5 m (Lieske and Myers 1994). They spawn in groups and each pair claims a small section of the reef. Its eggs are laid on a cleared section of the coral and guarded by the parents (Kuiter and Tonozuka 2001). This species is closely associated with branching Acropora corals (Allen 1991). Conversely, it is not found in areas without branching Acropora corals.

Longevity data for the family Pomacentridae suggest that these species reach a maximum of around 10 years in the wild (Allen 1991). Pomacentrids mature fairly early, typically between 1-2 years and the average mature age is 3-4 years in a population. Thus, we infer that the generation length is about 3-4 years.
threats: This species is closely associated with branching Acropora, which has undergone significant declines (coastal development, destructive fishing methods, increased bleaching events presumably due to climate change) throughout most of the range of this species; therefore, its habitat is under threat.
population:
Amblyglyphidodon ternatensis is locally abundant in some parts of its range (Allen pers. comm. 2010). It is especially abundant around the rock islands in Palau. It is very common in sheltered mangrove-lined channels in the Solomon Islands (G. Allen pers. comm. 2010).

This species is closely associated with branching Acropora corals. In northern Papua New Guinea, particularly in Madang Lagoon, Acropora cover has been declining over the past 13 years, with associated declines in A. ternatensis (A. Jenkins pers. comm. 2010). Fish transect data recorded almost every year for the past 13 years has measured a population decline in this species of approximately 75% in northern Papua New Guinea (A. Jenkins pers. comm. 2010). We infer that Acropora declines throughout this species' range would result in similar population declines of A. ternatensis.

From 1998-2004 there was a 30% overall destruction of coral reefs, of which 8% has recovered. In 2004, 28% of coral reefs remaining were considered to be at the critical stage (Wilkinson 2004). Of those coral reefs destroyed, Acropora is considered most affected in coral cover declines and a high percentage of Acropora in this region are considered vulnerable to extinction (Carpenter et al. 2008).

Based on these data, we infer that the A. ternatensis population is also declining at a rate greater than 30% over the last three generations (9-12 years).
range: Amblyglyphidodon ternatensis is found in the Coral Triangle, including Indonesia, Philippines, Papua New Guinea, Palau, Solomon Islands, and Vanuatu (Allen 1991).
useTrade: There is no use/trade information for this species.
conservationActions: This species is found in numerous marine protected areas (MPAs) throughout its range. However, population declines are still occurring in at least some of these MPAs (A. Jenkins pers. comm. 2010).

rationale: The Shortjaw Bonefish occurs from Hawaii and French Polynesia to the Seychelles in the western Indian Ocean, north to southern Japan and south to Lord Howe Island, Australia. Reflecting results in Colborn et al. (2001), the geographic range of A. glossodonta is likely representative of multiple species. Data on population decline are available from only a few locations, despite the expansive geographic range. In Tarawa, there has been a dramatic increase in scale of effort and modernization of the fishing gears. In 1977, bonefish comprised 44.6% of the total catch; in 1992, they comprised only 7.5% of the total catch. This decline (37.1% in 15 years) was a result of overfishing, as opposed to a change in fishing method and effort (Beets 2000). Spawning aggregations are often targeted (Beets 2000). In Tarawa Lagoon, Kiribati, recent studies have demonstrated significant declines in abundance and average size of bonefish in the catch between 1977 and the late 1990s. Given fisheries characteristics throughout the region, we expect that in areas where bonefish are exposed to fishing effort that Tarawa serves as an example of what would likely occur in other areas throughout its range.  In addition, although data on population decline is limited, this species may be closely associated with mangroves and seagrasses and other shallow coastal habitats. Valiela et al.(2001) estimate that mangroves have decreased worldwide by 35%, at a rate of 2% per year.  Using this estimate, mangroves have declined global by an estimated 27% over the last three generation lengths for A. glossodonta (13.5 years).  Much of this species' distribution lies in the Indo-Pacific, where up to 14% of mangrove species are listed as threatened (Vulnerable, Endangered, or Critically Endangered) in some places (Polidoro et al. 2010).  The Indo-Malay Philippine Archipelago is of particular concern, as it has one of the highest rates of mangrove loss globally, with an estimated 30% reduction in mangrove area since 1980 (FAO 2007).  In the tropical Indo-Pacific, 12% of all seagrasses are currently threatened, and 20% of all seagrass species are experiencing declines.  In the temperate North Pacific, the northern-most part of A. glossodonta's range, 22% of all seagrass species are threatened, and 44% are experiencing population declines (Short et al. 2011).  Given the  declines in these habitats, we infer that the extreme habitat loss in parts of its Pacific range will have similar negative consequences for population trajectories. In addition, the recreational fishery is not well-established in the Indo-Pacific region, so there is little economic incentive for conservation; we do not expect conservation to be occurring at present. Therefore, we estimate global decline to equal or exceed 30% over three generation lengths in the past (13.5 years), with some substantially greater localized depletions in parts of the Indo-Pacific. Perhaps the greatest hindrances to the global conservation of this species are uncertainties about population connectivity and taxonomic resolution. This species is currently listed as Vulnerable under A2bcd.
habitat:
This species is found on shallow flats, sandy bottoms, seagrass beds, mangrove shorelines and reef and rubble habitats. Like A. vulpes, A. glossodonta may be closely associated with mangroves and seagrasses and other shallow coastal habitats. Valiela et al. (2001) estimates that mangroves have decreased worldwide by 35%, at a rate of 2% per year. Using this estimate, mangroves have declined global by an estimated 27% over the last three generation lengths for A. glossodonta (13.5 years).  Much of this species' distribution lies in the Indo-Pacific, where up to 14% of mangrove species are listed as threatened (Vulnerable, Endangered, or Critically Endangered) in some places (Polidoro et al. 2010). The Indo-Malay Philippine Archipelago is of particular concern, as it has one of the highest rates of mangrove loss globally, with an estimated 30% reduction in mangrove area since 1980 (FAO 2007). In the tropical Indo-Pacific, 12% of all seagrasses are currently threatened, and 20% of all seagrass species are experiencing declines. In the temperate North Pacific, the northern-most part of A. glossodonta's range, 22% of all seagrass species are threatened, and 44% are experiencing population declines (Short et al. 2011). Given the declines in these habitats, we infer that the extreme habitat loss in parts of its Pacific range will have similar negative consequences for population trajectories.

Larvae of A. glossodonta are morphologically indistinguishable from A. argentea (then listed as A. forsteri) (Friedlander et al. 2008). Mean larval stage is 56 days (Friedlander et al. 2008). Maximum age recorded is 11 years  (Friedlander et al. 2008). Sex ratio varies widely across its distribution (1 to 1.25 in a study by Friedlander and 1–6.75 in another (Beets 2000). Although minimum size and age at maturity is not known, Albula sp. reared in the lab were sexually mature at two and three years of age (Pfeiler et al. 2000). Using equation number five of section 4.4 of the Guidelines for Using the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (IUCN Standards and Petitions Working Group 2008), if generation length = age of first reproduction + z*(length of the reproductive period), and age at first reproduction is estimated at 2.5 years, z is estimated to be 0.5 based on survivorship and relative fecundity with age, and the length of the reproductive period is estimated at 8.5 years, then generation length is estimated to be 4.5 years.

This species primarily feeds on crustaceans, including mantis shrimps and crab, also polychaetes, bivalves and amphipods (Friedlander 1997). Crustaceans comprised more than 50% of the diet in a Hawaiian study (Friedlander 1997).

Natural mortality from sharks is very high at Palmyra Atoll (Adams pers. comm. 2011). The maximum size for this species is 90 cm (SL) (Myers 1991).
threats:
Commercial landings of bonefish in Hawaii have decreased dramatically over the past few decades, presumably because of overfishing and loss of habitat, from over 300,000lbs in 1900 to less than 3,000lbs. since 2002. Bonefish were the most important species in the commercial seine fishery between 1966 and 1970, with average annual yields of nearly 18,000 pounds. Although the presence of multiple species within the fishery makes species-specific declines hard to pinpoint, the commercial seine catch now averages only 581lbs per year, accounting for less than 8% of the catch. Commercial landings of bonefish in Hawaii have declined from over 136.4 mt in 1900 to only 1.2 mt in 2001. This figure, however, includes all bonefish species in Hawaii (Friedlander et al. 2008).

Heavy fishing pressure and degradation of habitats at Tarawa and Kiritimati Atolls have resulted in the loss of pre-spawning staging sites and spawning migration routes, which may be responsible for the observed declines in bonefish catches, average size, and sex ratios at these locations (Friedlander et al. 2008). There are declines in CPUE, mean length and weight of fish and also a change in sex ratio (Beets 2000). Sex ratio (F:M) was 0.71:1 in 1977 and in 1992–1993 it was recorded as 0.15:1. In 1977, mean length was 46.4 cm and mean weight was 1.3 kg. In 1992, mean length recorded was 37.6 cm and mean weight was 0.84 kg. There was a decrease in the smallest size of sexually mature individuals between the two time periods: in 1977 the smallest size of sexually mature males was 42.5 cm  and 46.5 cm for females; in 1992 is was 32 cm for males and 35 cm for females. In addition, Beets (2000) conservatively estimates that the 30% of total catch was non-reproductive. In Tarawa, there has been a dramatic increase in scale of effort and modernization of the fishing gears. In 1977, bonefish comprised 44.6% of the total catch; in 1992, they comprised only 7.5% of the total catch. Spawning aggregations are often targeted (Beets 2000). The effects of catch-and-release fishing on this species are unclear.

Unrestrained growth of human populations in the coastal zones has also accelerated habitat destruction, water quality degradation, and disruption of prey species dynamics. Fishing and habitat loss and degradation may pose the most significant threats to this species. Disruptions to shallow coastal ecosystems such as seagrasses and mangroves due to climate change may pose significant future threats to this species, particularly in areas with accelerated rates of coastal development and urbanization.

The limited range of this species may also make it vulnerable to local threats, such as habitat loss (Friedlander et al. 2008). It has been noted that habitat alteration, fragmentation and loss may contribute to the decline in abundance of this species in Tarawa (Beets 2000). Bonefish are closely associated with mangroves,seagrasses and other shallow coastal habitats. Given the dramatic declines in these habitats (Mumby et al. 2004, Valiela et al. 2001, Polidoro et al. 2010, Orth et al. 2006, Short et al. 2011), we infer that comparable regional declines are likely throughout its range. Valiela et al. (2001) estimates that mangroves have decreased worldwide by 35%, at a rate of 2% per year. Since bonefish rely upon habitats of limited extent, they are especially susceptible to habitat loss and degradation, particularly due to climatic and anthropogenic influences. These habitats are often fragmented in nature, exacerbating this issue. As with other coastal species, fragmentation will likely have direct and indirect negative impacts on bonefish.
population:
As multiple species within the genus are morphologically indistinguishable, there is limited species-specific information available on population status. Commercial landings of bonefish in Hawaii have declined from over 136.4 mt in 1900 to only 1.2 mt in 2001. This figure, however, includes all bonefish species in Hawaii (Friedlander et al. 2008). A recreational fishing guide on Oahu indicated that although netting of bonefish continues, it is not as prevalent as it once was (Adams pers. comm. 2011). It is therefore unclear whether the decline in landings is due to a change in effort or a true change in population size. Capture of recruits (CPUE) of Albula spp. in Kahana, Hawaii was highest in 1999 and has declined by 79% since that time (Friedlander et al. 2008).

This species is rare in Mauritius (Sato et al. 2008).

In Tarawa, there has been a dramatic increase in scale of effort and modernization of the fishing gears. In 1977, bonefish comprised 44.6% of the total catch; in 1992, they were 7.5% of the total catch. This decline (37.1% in 15 years) was a result of overfishing, as opposed to a change in fishing method and effort (Beets 2000). Spawning aggregations are often targeted (Beets 2000). A survey from the Fisheries Division of Kiribati conducted in 1995 shows that bonefish was the second-most common species caught, accounting for 7% of total catch. Gill nets caught 82% of the bonefish, with handlines providing the remainder (18%) of the catch (Friedlander et al. 2008). In Tarawa Lagoon, Kiribati, recent studies have demonstrated significant declines in abundance and average size of bonefish in the catch between 1977 and the late 1990s. The annual take of bonefish from Tarawa Lagoon is between 1,000,000 and 5,000,000 fish per year, but no stock assessment has been conducted (Friedlander et al. 2008). This species is probably the most abundant molluscivorous fish in the lagoon (Beets 2001). Comparison data from fished and protected locations at Palmyra Atoll show significant differences in population characteristics which may indicate that threats are expressed asymmetrically across its range (Adams pers. comm. 2011).  Given fisheries characteristics throughout the region, we expect that in areas where bonefish are exposed to fishing effort that Tarawa serves as an example of what would likely occur in other areas throughout its range. In addition, the recreational fishery is not well-established in the Indo-Pacific, so there is little economic incentive for conservation.  Therefore, we do not expect conservation to be occurring at present.

Like A. vulpes, A. glossodonta  may be closely associated with mangroves and seagrasses and other shallow coastal habitats. Valiela et al. (2001) estimate that mangroves have decreased worldwide by 35%, at a rate of 2% per year.   Using this estimate, mangroves have declined global by an estimated 27% over the last three generation lengths for A. glossodonta (13.5 years).  Much of this species' distribution lies in the Indo-Pacific, where up to 14% of mangrove species are listed as threatened (Vulnerable, Endangered, or Critically Endangered) in some places (Polidoro et al. 2010).  The Indo-Malay Philippine Archipelago is of particular concern, as it has one of the highest rates of mangrove loss globally, with an estimated 30% reduction in mangrove area since 1980 (FAO 2007).  In the tropical Indo-Pacific, 12% of all seagrasses are currently threatened, and 20% of all seagrass species are experiencing declines.  In the temperate North Pacific, the northern-most part of A. glossodonta's range, 22% of all seagrass species are threatened, and 44% are experiencing population declines (Short et al. 2011).  Given the  declines in these habitats, we infer that the extreme habitat loss in parts of its Pacific range will have similar negative consequences for population trajectories.

Given population declines of at least 30%  over three generation lengths at Tarawa, significant habitat loss throughout much of its range, we estimate global decline to equal or exceed 30% over three generation lengths (13.5 years), with some substantially greater localized depletions in parts of the Indo-Pacific.
range: The Shortjaw Bonefish occurs from Hawaii and French Polynesia to the Seychelles in the western Indian Ocean, north to southern Japan and south to Lord Howe Island, Australia. Its type locality is in the Red Sea (Bowen et al. 2008). Reflecting results in Colborn et al. (2001), the geographic range of A. glossodonta is likely representative of multiple species.
useTrade: Bonefishes are targeted by commercial, recreational, and subsistence fishers throughout the Pacific, including the Hawaiian Islands and Cooke Islands. Subsistence fishing for bonefish in locations such as Tarawa consists of one of the most important protein sources for the island's human population (Friedlander et al. 2008).
conservationActions: State regulations in Hawaii recently raised the minimum size regulation from 23 cm (9 in.) total length (TL) to 36 cm (14 in.) TL, although there is neither a closed season nor bag limit (Friedlander et al. 2008). Albula glossodonta likely occurs in Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) in parts of its range. In addition, the recreational fishery is not well-established in the much of the Indo-Pacific, so there is little economic incentive for conservation.

rationale: This newly described species is found from the east coast of South Africa to Thailand  (Hidaka et al. 2008), including Mozambique, Mauritius, Seychelles, Somalia, Yemen, Oman, India. There is an apparent disjunct population segment in the Great Barrier Reef of Australia. There is very little known about the life history, ecology, population status, or threats acting upon this species. However, it may be impacted by habitat degradation and loss, declining water quality and exploitation. Therefore, it is listed as Data Deficient.
habitat: Little species-specific information exists regarding the habitat and ecology of A. oligolepis. Maximum length observed for this shallow water species is 35.4 cm TL (Hidaka et al. 2008).
threats: This species is likely targeted today by a mix of commercial, recreational and subsistence  fishers but there are no data specific to this species. It may occur as by-catch.
